Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Immunohistochemistry, western blots, microscopy!
I developed some basic bio lab skills, like staining and looking at tissues on slides and Western blotting.
Immunohistochemistry, Western blot, histology
Learning about immunohistochemistry and to recognize cell structures and histology in placenta as well as the male and female reproductive tract.
I gained hands-on experience in the research methodologies used to study the reproductive system.
Immunohistochemistry, Western Blotting, staining, reproductive anatomy

This course taught me a lot about immunohistochemistry, as well as the techniques used in the lab to visualize cells and tissues. The tissues we used were all from the reproductive tract, which helped to cement concepts from the MCDB 250 lecture course.
I learned relevant lab techniques as well as gained a greater understanding of biology.

This course goes over the structure and function of human placental and other reproductive tissues and teaches the protocols and principles of immunohistochemistry, western blotting, and hematoxylin and eosin staining.
This class was incredibly accommodating and fun to be a part of. I learned effortlessly, thanks to the well-organized nature of the class and the moderate workload.

The strengths of this course were the great professors.
The weaknesses were that many of the laboratories had a lot of empty down time that was quite annoying. Also, many of the techniques were repeated between labs, making it slightly monotonous.

Strengths - format of the lab report, content of the lab, collaborative nature of the course
Weaknesses - maybe give students access to the lab report beforehand?

Straightforward, interesting, and low-work lab class the complements the lecture well. Highly recommend! Assignments assess what you learned in lab without being stressful, confusing, or unnecessarily time-consuming. The lab techniques used (Western blot, immunohistochemistry, H&E staining) were well explained and well applied to the subject of reproductive biology. I honestly don't think this lab could be improved at all, I wish all the MCDB labs took the approach of this one (emphasize learning without busywork).

Strength: learned about reproductive organ structures

weaknesses: n/a

The labs were all really interesting and informative
As we discussed in class, I did hope that we could have more engagement/discussion about the papers instead of just lecture-style

The class is great in that it teaches information and techniques in a low-stress setting, which made it really easy to learn.  It was pretty low in terms of workload though, and it doesn't feel like we covered a particularly broad amount of content.

The course is a great introduction to tissue staining and cell visualization techniques, and I feel that I have a much stronger grasp of the the lab techniques after taking this methods course. I feel that the course could benefit from a few more graded assignments though. The lab work was relatively simple, but it could often be difficult to figure out hat was expected on lab reports. Because there are only a few of these assignments, a less-than-stellar grade on one can greatly affect a student's final grade, even if the students was dedicate to the course and was able to properly conduct the lab work. This could often feel frustrating, as the level of difficulty in the course was not high enough to warrant final grades below a certain level, but not every students will hit the grade they feel reflects their lab output because so few graded assignments exist. I really enjoyed the course overall though, and have highly recommended it to several students.
This was THE best lab course I took at Yale! Perfect combination of lab and biology. Very reasonable in expectations. I learned so much and it was an enjoyable experience!

The lab ordering could be improved by grouping labs on tissue type instead of technique to limit the amount of backtracking needed to remember past material. The protocols were very streamlined and easy to follow, making it easier to focus on interpreting the results instead of getting stuck on procedure, which I thought was a strength of the course. The course may also benefit from adding focus on discussing papers during downtime with more participation from the students.
This was my favorite lab at Yale (and I've taken 8). If you want a lab that will teach you something without making you loathe/dread your afternoons spent in lab, this is it.
I would highly recommend this course! It's low-stress and you learn so much about staining techniques.

Absolutely! You learn super interesting material, lab itself is low stress, the assignments are straightforward and the grading is fair. Seth Guller is kind and is so invested in making the lab a positive experience for the students in it. A true gem!
Yes - learn about interesting reproductive biology with balanced workload.
This is a great lab to take for MCDB majors! Definitely recommend!
Yes, definitely.  Super low stress and you learn a lot, and Seth is really passionate and accessible.
Yes!
